This adds more results on Jacobi sums.

</details>

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10796832833/job/29946728504)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10796832833/job/29946728813)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

What do you think of
```suggestion
  have : ∑ x ∈ univ \ {0, 1}, ((1 : MulChar F R) x - 1) * (χ (1 - x) - 1) = 0 := by
    apply Finset.sum_eq_zero
    simp (config := { contextual := true }) [MulChar.one_apply, ← isUnit_iff_ne_zero]
  rw [jacobiSum_eq_aux, MulChar.sum_eq_zero_of_ne_one hχ, MulChar.sum_one_eq_card_units,
    Fintype.card_eq_card_units_add_one (α := F), this, Nat.cast_add]
  ring
```
Mine is twice as fast, but this is because you did not squeeze the `simp` (and `ring`).

Not sure if this is an improvement, but I factored out that bijection:
```suggestion
lemma Set.BijOn.of_inverse {α β : Type*} {s : Set α} {t : Set β} (f : α → β) (g : β → α)
    (hf : MapsTo f s t) (hg : MapsTo g t s)
    (hfg : ∀ x ∈ s, g (f x) = x) (hgf : ∀ y ∈ t, f (g y) = y) :
    Set.BijOn f s t := by
  refine ⟨hf, ?_, ?_⟩
  · intro x hx y hy h
    rw [← hfg x hx, ← hfg y hy, h]
  · intro x hx
    use g x
    exact ⟨hg hx, hgf _ hx⟩

lemma div_sub_bijOn (a : F) (ha : a ≠ 0) :
    Set.BijOn (fun x ↦ x / (a - x)) (univ \ {a} : Finset F) (univ \ {-1} : Finset F) := by
  apply Set.BijOn.of_inverse _ (fun y ↦ a * y / (1 + y))
  all_goals
    intro x hx
    simp only [mem_coe, mem_sdiff, mem_univ, mem_singleton, true_and] at hx ⊢
  · rw [eq_comm, ← sub_eq_zero] at hx
    field_simp
    rw [← sub_eq_zero]
    ring_nf
    exact ha
  · rw [eq_neg_iff_add_eq_zero, add_comm] at hx
    field_simp [ha]
  · rw [eq_comm, ← sub_eq_zero] at hx
    field_simp
  · rw [eq_neg_iff_add_eq_zero, add_comm] at hx
    field_simp
    ring_nf
    field_simp

lemma Finset.sum_bijOn {α β A : Type*} [AddCommMonoid A]
    {s : Finset α} {t : Finset β} (f : α → β) (g : β → A) (h : Set.BijOn f s t) :
    ∑ x in s, g (f x) = ∑ y in t, g y :=
  sum_nbij f h.mapsTo h.injOn h.surjOn (fun _ _ ↦ rfl)

/-- If `χ` is a nontrivial multiplicative character on a finite field `F`,
then `J(χ,χ⁻¹) = -χ(-1)`. -/
theorem jacobiSum_nontrivial_inv {χ : MulChar F R} (hχ : χ ≠ 1) : jacobiSum χ χ⁻¹ = -χ (-1) := by
  rw [jacobiSum]
  conv => enter [1, 2, x]; rw [MulChar.inv_apply', ← map_mul, ← div_eq_mul_inv]
  have : ∑ x ∈ univ \ {1}, χ (x / (1 - x)) = ∑ x ∈ univ \ {-1}, χ x :=
    Finset.sum_bijOn _ _ (div_sub_bijOn 1 one_ne_zero)
  rw [sum_eq_sum_diff_singleton_add (mem_univ (1 : F)), this, sum_sdiff_eq_sub (subset_univ _),
    MulChar.sum_eq_zero_of_ne_one hχ]
  simp [χ.map_zero]
```
I really wish that automation would be better at proving the bijection.
I think the addition of the helper lemmas is better done in a separate PR; after that is merged, we can refactor.

Some ψ's in the docstring should be φ's. How essential is the hypothesis that F be a field here? I think it should be true for any finite ring, as long as `χ * φ` is primitive; certainly this is the case for `ZMod N`.

Fixed the docstring.

What does "primitive" mean for general multiplicative characters? Can you give a precise statement and proof?
Note that when one character is trivial (and the other one, say `χ`, is primitive), the statement is equivalent to the sum of `ψ x` over all non-units `x` being equal to the sum of `χ (1 - x)` over all non-units `x`, which may be true, but is not that obvious (e.g., the first sum does not always have the same value).

In any case, the present proof breaks down; to make it work, one would need that the sum over `χ x * φ (a - x)` vanishes when `a` is a non-unit (or at least, that the sum of these sums over all non-units `a` vanishes), and I don't quite see how to do that when `a` is not zero.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/JacobiSum/Basic): more Jacobi sum values
